title: Change in amount of oxygen difluoride

content.description: <math alttext="2 F 2, gas, plus, 2 N a O H, aqueous, react to produce, O F 2, gas, plus, 2 N a F, aqueous, plus, H 2 O, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>â†’</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>OF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>F</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: A <math alttext="2 mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="F 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with excess <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>aO</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> according to the equation above. If the reaction is repeated with excess <math alttext="N a O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>aO</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> but with <math alttext="1 mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>1 mol</mtext></mrow></math> of <math alttext="F 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, which of the following is correct?

choices.label: The amount of <math alttext="O F 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>OF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> produced is doubled.

The amount of <math alttext="O F 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>OF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> produced is halved.

The amount of <math alttext="N a F, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>aF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> produced remains the same.

The amount of <math alttext="N a F, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mtext>aF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> produced is doubled.

content.answer: The amount of <math alttext="O F 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>OF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> produced is halved.

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
